member.name: P:LanguageServer.Parameters.General.CompletionItemCapabilities.snippetSupport
member.summary: Client supports snippets as insert text.
member.remarks: A snippet can define tab stops and placeholders with $1, $2 and ${3:foo}. $0 defines the final tab stop, it defaults to the end of the snippet. Placeholders with equal identifiers are linked, that is typing in one will update others too.

remarks.para: When this property exists the client also guarantees that it will handle values outside its set gracefully and falls back to a default value when unknown.

member.name: T:LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.CodeAction
member.summary: For textDocument/codeAction

remarks.para: A code action represents a change that can be performed in code, e.g. to fix a problem or to refactor code.
A CodeAction must set either edit and/or a command. If both are supplied, the edit is applied first, then the command is executed.

member.remarks: Represents programming constructs like variables, classes, interfaces etc. that appear in a document. Document symbols can be hierarchical and they have two ranges: one that encloses its definition and one that points to its most interesting range, e.g. the range of an identifier.

member.name: P:LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.DocumentSymbol.detail
member.summery: More detail for this symbol, e.g the signature of a function. If not provided the name is used.

member.name: P:LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.DocumentSymbol.deprecated
member.summery: Indicates if this symbol is deprecated.

member.name: P:LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.DocumentSymbol.range
member.summery: The range enclosing this symbol not including leading/trailing whitespace but everything else like comments. This information is typically used to determine if the the clients cursor is inside the symbol to reveal in the symbol in the UI.

member.name: P:LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.DocumentSymbol.selectionRange
member.summery: The range that should be selected and revealed when this symbol is being picked, e.g the name of a function. Must be contained by the the range.

member.name: P:LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.DocumentSymbol.children
member.summery: Children of this symbol, e.g. properties of a class.

member.name: T:LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.MarkedString
member.summary: MarkedString can be used to render human readable text.

remarks.para: It is either a markdown string or a code-block that provides a language and a code snippet. The language identifier is semantically equal to the optional language identifier in fenced code blocks in GitHub issues. See https://help.github.com/articles/creating-and-highlighting-code-blocks/#syntax-highlighting
Note that markdown strings will be sanitized - that means html will be escaped.
MarkedString is deprecated. use MarkupContent instead.

member.name: P:LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.MarkedString.language
member.summary: The language in which the code block is written.

member.name: P:LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.MarkedString.value
member.summary: The code block.

member.name: T:LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.MarkupContent
member.summary: For textDocument/completion and textDocument/hover

remarks.para: A MarkupContent literal represents a string value which content is interpreted base on its kind flag. Currently the protocol supports plaintext and markdown as markup kinds.
If the kind is markdown then the value can contain fenced code blocks like in GitHub issues. See https://help.github.com/articles/creating-and-highlighting-code-blocks/#syntax-highlighting

member.name: P:LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.MarkupContent.kind
member.summary: The type of the Markup
member.value:
plaintext Plain text is supported as a content format
markdown Markdown is supported as a content format
See for an enumeration of standardized kinds.

member.name: P:LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.MarkupContent.value
member.summary: The content itself

member.summary: The active signature.

remarks.para: If omitted or the value lies outside the range of signatures the value defaults to zero or is ignored if signatures.length === 0. Whenever possible implementors should make an active decision about the active signature and shouldn't rely on a default value.
In future version of the protocol this property might become mandatory to better express this.

member.summary: The active parameter of the active signature.

remarks.para: If omitted or the value lies outside the range of signatures[activeSignature].parameters defaults to 0 if the active signature has parameters. If the active signature has no parameters it is ignored.
In future version of the protocol this property might become mandatory to better express the active parameter if the active signature does have any.

member.name: M:LanguageServer.Server.TextDocumentServiceTemplate.Completion(LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.CompletionParams)
member.summary: The Completion request is sent from the client to the server to compute completion items at a given cursor position.

remarks.para: Completion items are presented in the IntelliSense user interface. If computing full completion items is expensive, servers can additionally provide a handler for the completion item resolve request (completionItem/resolve).
This request is sent when a completion item is selected in the user interface.

A typical use case is for example: the textDocument/completion request doesn’t fill in the documentation property for returned completion items since it is expensive to compute. When the item is selected in the user interface then a completionItem/resolve request is sent with the selected completion item as a param.
Registration Options: CompletionRegistrationOptions

member.name: M:LanguageServer.Server.TextDocumentServiceTemplate.DocumentSymbols(LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.DocumentSymbolParams)
member.summary: The document symbol request is sent from the client to the server to return a flat list of all symbols found in a given text document.

remarks.para: Neither the symbol’s location range nor the symbol’s container name should be used to infer a hierarchy.
Registration Options: TextDocumentRegistrationOptions

member.name: M:LanguageServer.Server.TextDocumentServiceTemplate.DocumentColor(LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.DocumentColorParams)
member.summary: The document color request is sent from the client to the server to list all color references found in a given text document. Along with the range, a color value in RGB is returned.
member.remarks:
Clients can use the result to decorate color references in an editor. For example:
Color boxes showing the actual color next to the reference
Show a color picker when a color reference is edited

member.name: M:LanguageServer.Server.TextDocumentServiceTemplate.ColorPresentation(LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.ColorPresentationParams)
member.summary: The color presentation request is sent from the client to the server to obtain a list of presentations for a color value at a given location.
member.remarks:
Clients can use the result to
modify a color reference.
show in a color picker and let users pick one of the presentations

member.remarks: Registration Options: TextDocumentRegistrationOptions

member.name: M:LanguageServer.Server.TextDocumentServiceTemplate.CodeAction(LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.CodeActionParams)
member.summary: The code action request is sent from the client to the server to compute commands for a given text document and range.

remarks.para: These commands are typically code fixes to either fix problems or to beautify/refactor code. The result of a textDocument/codeAction request is an array of Command literals which are typically presented in the user interface. When the command is selected the server should be contacted again (via the workspace/executeCommand request) to execute the command.

Since version 3.8.0: support for CodeAction literals to enable the following scenarios:
the ability to directly return a workspace edit from the code action request. This avoids having another server roundtrip to execute an actual code action. However server providers should be aware that if the code action is expensive to compute or the edits are huge it might still be beneficial if the result is simply a command and the actual edit is only computed when needed.
the ability to group code actions using a kind. Clients are allowed to ignore that information. However it allows them to better group code action for example into corresponding menus (e.g. all refactor code actions into a refactor menu).
Clients need to announce their support for code action literals and code action kinds via the corresponding client capability textDocument.codeAction.codeActionLiteralSupport.
Registration Options: TextDocumentRegistrationOptions

member.name: M:LanguageServer.Server.TextDocumentServiceTemplate.FoldingRange(LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.FoldingRangeRequestParam)
member.summary: The folding range request is sent from the client to the server to return all folding ranges found in a given text document.

member.name: M:LanguageServer.ServiceConnection.CodeAction(LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.CodeActionParams)
member.summary: The code action request is sent from the client to the server to compute commands for a given text document and range.

remarks.para: These commands are typically code fixes to either fix problems or to beautify/refactor code. The result of a textDocument/codeAction request is an array of Command literals which are typically presented in the user interface. When the command is selected the server should be contacted again (via the workspace/executeCommand request) to execute the command.

Since version 3.8.0: support for CodeAction literals to enable the following scenarios:
the ability to directly return a workspace edit from the code action request. This avoids having another server roundtrip to execute an actual code action. However server providers should be aware that if the code action is expensive to compute or the edits are huge it might still be beneficial if the result is simply a command and the actual edit is only computed when needed.
the ability to group code actions using a kind. Clients are allowed to ignore that information. However it allows them to better group code action for example into corresponding menus (e.g. all refactor code actions into a refactor menu).
Clients need to announce their support for code action literals and code action kinds via the corresponding client capability textDocument.codeAction.codeActionLiteralSupport.
Registration Options: TextDocumentRegistrationOptions

member.name: M:LanguageServer.ServiceConnection.FoldingRange(LanguageServer.Parameters.TextDocument.FoldingRangeRequestParam)
